awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamic Clustering and Rheology of Magnetic Janus Particles with Shifted Dipoles
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the project is to engineer the flowability of a fluid, i.e., the ease with which a fluid flows, by addition of active magnetic particles with unique magnetic properties. These particles can be manipulated by a combination of an external magnetic field and an internal chemical gradient. Fluids with varying flowability are important for common technologies, such as printers, fluid shock absorbers, fluid property sensors, biomedical devices, and body armor. Control of the flowability will enable longer lifetimes, broader applicability, reduced cost, and increased stability of the fluids and devices. The proposed research will investigate the assembly properties of active magnetic colloids using experimental and computational techniques. Additional benefits of these studies are the creation of a toolbox for the design of fluids that have their flowability tailored to a particular application.   

The research addresses the need for an in-depth understanding of the assembly behavior of active magnetic Janus particles with shifted dipoles. In systems with shifted dipoles, the magnetic dipole axis is shifted away from the center of mass of the particle, thereby providing additional control over particle orientation and response. In combination with on-board propulsion, particles with shifted dipoles represent a new and exciting class of active materials. The research described will advance our understanding of magnetic particle interaction, active matter, and the rheology of complex magnetic fluids. This work will enable future studies in which, for example, Brownian Dynamics simulations are used to predict long-time dynamics and to discover novel structures that are difficult to accomplish or detect experimentally. More broadly, research described in the proposal will advance our understanding of the intrinsic role of forces and torques in the structure of complex fluids, thus providing important insights into the statistical physics of out-of-equilibrium systems and enabling researchers to better engineer and utilize many body dynamics in the microscopic regime. The educational goals of this proposal will leverage the collaborative environment between the two participating institutions to enhance student education at various stages and thereby strengthen the diversity of the STEM workforce pipeline.

por.por_cntn:
The anisotropic properties given by the implementation of a displacement of the magnetic dipole on magnetic colloids, provide a potential key for the development of new materials and applications such as drug delivery, cell targeting, and imaging techniques, among others. In this research project, the self-assembly of magnetic Janus colloids, with the dipole shifting radially or lateral from the center of mass to the surface of the particle, is developed using Brownian Dynamics simulations to understand the fundamentals of cluster formation and to discover insights on their dynamic aggregation processes. This project is directly relevant to the development of new colloidal systems and provides the opportunity to implement a multi-disciplinary approach, which has the potential to be adopted with the objective of generating advances in the nanofabrication field, which in consequence, will play a major role in the field of soft matter physics. 

The focus of the investigation is the effect of the dipole displacement (s) from the center of mass of the particle (s=0.0) towards the surface (s=1.0). We observed that the lateral displacement of the magnetic dipole allows the creation of rings whose radius we can control with the magnitude of the displacement, being more compact rings having high displacements. On the other hand, radial displacement gives us a rich diversity of structures, which we have cataloged into three different aggregation groups: Head-to-Tail aggregation for small displacements (s < 0.3), Bidirectional aggregation for intermediate displacements (0.3 < s < 0.6), and Double-Chain aggregation for long shifts (0.6 < s). These aggregations, together with the variation in the relationship between magnetic force and the Brownian effect, generate a rich variety of structures, such as single-chain, loop-like, island-like, worm-like, and antiparallel-double- chain clusters.

The intellectual merit of this award includes an approach to assembling magnetic Janus nanoparticles in three-dimensions at a colloidal scale. These Janus colloids whose two faces have a surface pattern with anisotropic properties that provides many advantages and play a crucial role in the discovery and design of new materials and complex fluid. Janus magnetic colloids characterized by magnetic properties are susceptible to magnetic fields which broaden their range of applications. In addition, a relevant aspect to consider when studying the behavior of a system of magnetic Janus colloids is the focus of the dynamic aggregation and how new behavior and structures formed could observe under determined conditions, such as self-propulsion or under influence shear flow which directly affects the transport of particles due to collective effects that development in these phenomena.

The broader impacts of this award include discovering a rich diversity of structures, that are easy to manufacture and repeat, allowing to have a catalog of structures suitable for various types of applications. Additionally, the behavior induced by self-propulsion or shearing of magnetic colloids opens the door to broad applications of these particles in a non-equilibrium state, having a direct impact on the development of many applications aimed at medical issues, such as the administration of drugs or the treatment of specific cancer cells. Also in the environmental field, there are many applications of these nanoparticles as biosensors that are applied to remedial treatment to remove contaminants from water suspensions.
